All operating and functional areas
Table of Contents
Additional Invoice Processing Information
for Summoned Witnesses
) The Summons Handbook provides guidelines for all IRS functions in one functional handbook. and (
) Purpose: This IRM provides instructional procedures relating to the and processing of summons invoices. (

) Audience: All employees authorized to obligate appropriated funds for payment of search costs, reproduction costs, and transportation costs in nection with third-party summonses issued under the Internal Revenue (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy, SBSE. (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy Enforcement, SBSE. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Employees who prepare and approve summons invoices. (
) Program Goals: Provide guidance and procedures relating to the payment summons invoices. (

) The Summons Handbook provides guidelines for all IRS functions in one functional handbook. This section provides information concerning the of witness fees and other costs, invoice processing guidelines, and witness inquiries concerning payment of summons invoices associated with responses. (
) IRC

provides for the payment of witness fees and mileage to witnesses and the payment of search, reproduction, and transportation certain third-party witnesses. Third parties complying with a summons will paid under the terms and conditions as set forth in
CFR
) Search, reproduction, and transportation cost payments are in addition to not a substitute for a summoned witnesses’ right to witness fees and travel expenses. (
) IRC

provides for payments to third parties who request reimbursement for costs incurred in complying with a summons. Payments may be made to third parties without the issuance of a summons for records needed in an vestigation which are available to the general public. See IRM
, Claiming Reimbursement. (

) Delegation Order SBSE
provides the levels of authority delegated to obligate funds for payment to third parties who request reimbursement for cost of complying with a summons, Form
, Invoice and Authorization Payment of Administrative Summons Expenses. See IRM
, of Authority, for additional information. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
and Costs for Summoned Witnesses 25.5.9

Delegation Order SBSE 25-6-1 provides the levels of authority delegated to obligate funds for payment to third parties who request reimbursement for the cost of complying with a summons, Form 6863, Invoice and Authorization for Payment of Administrative Summons Expenses. See IRM 25.5.9.2,
) Delegation Order
provides the levels of authority delegated to various employees to approve and perform activities concerning summonses. (

) The Director, Headquarters Collection, is the executive responsible for providing policy and guidance for IRS employees and ensuring consistent plication of policy, procedures, and tax law to effect tax administration while protecting taxpayer rights. See IRM
, Headquarters Collection, for additional information. (
) The Director, Collection Policy, reports to the Director Headquarters and is responsible for the delivery of policy and guidance that impacts the summons program. See IRM
, Collection Policy, for additional mation. (
) The Program Manager, Enforcement, reports to the Director, Collection and is responsible for providing policy and procedural guidance on processes to employees. See IRM
, Enforcement, for guidance. (
) Paragraph (
) of Delegation Order
lists the employees delegated to summonses except “John Doe” summonses. (

) There are no servicewide program reports tracking summons issuance. The Collection Policy program analyst will periodically review summonses issued revenue officers to ensure taxpayer rights were protected during the process and to determine that all standards for preparation, issuance and service of the summonses were met. (
) Summons invoices are processed by the Chief Financial Officer (CFO), formerly known as Beckley Finance Center. (
) The IRS employee who issued the summons keeps the original summons invoice in their administrative case ﬁle. The summons invoice is subject to same retention standards as the case ﬁle. (

) The following is a list of terms commonly used by the IRS when a summons is served for books, records, and documents: Term Deﬁnition Taxpayer The person with respect to whose liability the summons is issued. Third Party Any person served with a summons other than: a. A taxpayer; or b. An officer, employee, agent, accountant, or attorney of a taxpayer who, at the time the summons is served, is acting as such. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
N
The following is a list of terms commonly used by the IRS when a third-party summons is served for books, records, and documents:

Term Deﬁnition Taxpayer The person with respect to whose liability the summons is issued. Third Party Any person served with a summons other than: a. A taxpayer; or b. An officer, employee, agent, accountant, or attorney of a taxpayer who, at the time the summons is served, is acting as such.
Fees and Costs for Summoned Witnesses

page 3 Term Deﬁnition Third Party Records Books, papers, records, or other data in which the taxpayer does not have a proprietary interest at the time the summons is served. Directly Incurred Costs Costs incurred solely, immedi- ately, and necessarily as a consequence of searching for, reproducing, or transporting records in order to comply with a summons. Directly incurred costs do not include proportional alloca- tion of ﬁxed costs, such as overhead and equipment depre- ciation. However, where a third- party’s records are stored at an independent storage facility that charges the third party a fee to search for, reproduce, or transport particular records requested, such fees are consid- ered to be directly incurred by the summoned third party and are payable at the same rate the summoned third party is entitled to receive under Treas. Reg., 301.7610-1, ($8.50/hour for personnel time used by the inde- pendent storage facility and $0.20/page for copies of documents produced by the inde- pendent storage facility).

Books, papers, records, or other data in which the taxpayer does not have a proprietary interest at the time the summons is served. Costs incurred solely, immedi- ately, and necessarily as a consequence of searching for, reproducing, or transporting records in order to comply with a summons. Directly incurred costs do not include proportional alloca- tion of ﬁxed costs, such as overhead and equipment depre- ciation. However, where a third- party’s records are stored at an independent storage facility that charges the third party a fee to search for, reproduce, or transport particular records requested, such fees are consid- ered to be directly incurred by the summoned third party and are payable at the same rate the summoned third party is entitled to receive under Treas. Reg.,
/hour for personnel time used by the inde- pendent storage facility and $
/page for copies of documents produced by the inde- pendent storage facility).

Term Deﬁnition Search Costs Include only: • The total cost of personnel time directly incurred in locating and retrieving records or information; and • Direct costs of extracting information stored by computer. Salaries of persons locating and re- trieving summoned material are not includible in search costs. Note: Persons are paid a set amount for time directly incurred regardless of their salary or wage. Also, search costs do not include salaries, fees, or similar expenditures for analysis of material or for managerial or legal advice, expertise, or research, nor does it include time spent for such activities. Reproduction Costs Costs incurred in making copies or duplicates of summoned documents, transcripts, and other similar material. Transportation Costs Costs incurred to transport personnel to search for records or information requested and costs incurred solely by the need to transport the summoned material to the place of examination.
The table below lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions.

) The Commissioner of Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has delegated to Area Directors, and to such persons as the Area Directors deem the authority to obligate appropriated funds for making payment for reproduction, and transportation costs in connection with complying with a third-party summons. See Delegation Order
As a result of this order, each business unit then delegates to the level of authority needed obligation of funds. (

) Throughout this IRM, the term “IRS employee” will be used to reﬂect an employee with delegated authority to issue summonses, such as a Officer, Revenue Agent, Tax Compliance Officer or a Special Agent. (

) IRS employees should estimate the obligation needed for payment of the of compliance with the summons and initiate the necessary administrative action to obtain the required level of approval authority under Area Orders, if needed. (
) IRC

provides for payments to third parties who request for costs incurred in complying with a summons. Payments may be made third parties without the issuance of a summons for records needed in an vestigation which are available to the general public. See IRM
, Claiming Reimbursement.

) No payment may be made under IRC
until the third party has rily complied with the summons and has submitted an itemized bill or per Treas. Reg.

) If a third party has satisfactorily complied with a summons but the invoice is determined to be incomplete, the agency shall: • Return the invoice to the witness as soon as practicable after but no later than seven calendar days after receipt of the invoice, and • Notify the witness in writing of all defects that prevent payment, and request invoice re-submission as soon as possible. The IRS ee’s notiﬁcation should clearly outline the actions necessary to complete, or perfect, the document. (

) The IRS must perfect and timely process and pay an invoice not returned the witness within seven calendar days of invoice receipt, but only when witness has ﬁrst satisfactorily complied with the summons. The IRS is responsible for perfecting and processing the invoice when the seven calendar day review time-frame is not met. (

) The IRS employee that issued the summons is in the best position to determine what costs are reasonable based on the type of documents and the age of the documents. Examples of allowed costs include: • Paper copies, when the same documents are not also included on storage media or by electronic transmission, paid at $
/page sided pages are counted as two separate pages) • Cost of storage media (such as CD, DVD and thumb drives) • Search (provided in number of hours spent to comply with the and paid at $
/hour) • Other costs (such as transportation, postage and shipping) (

) Examples of disallowed costs include: • Charges for duplicate records (if the IRS employee requests both tronic and paper copies, the IRS must pay for both the electronic paper copies) • Legal fees (Treas. Reg.
allows $

/hour for search and processing). Request the witness to correct the invoice and delete number of hours legal personnel spent reviewing the accuracy of the summoned records. • Certiﬁcation fee (only allowed if the IRS employee requested tion of the records) • Charges based on formulas (such as
statements an hour or
checks an hour). When this occurs, request the witness to correct invoice and provide the actual search hours spent complying with the summons. (

) Send an e-mail to *CFO BFC Summons Help Desk if there are charges on the invoice. Note: It is the IRS employee’s responsibility to notify the third party when a reduced, explaining the amount disallowed and the reason for the disallowance. The IRS employee or their manager can later allow the after additional information is provided by the third party. See IRM Previously Disallowed Expense.

It is the IRS employee’s responsibility to notify the third party when a claim is reduced, explaining the amount disallowed and the reason for the disallowance. The IRS employee or their manager can later allow the charge after additional information is provided by the third party. See IRM 25.5.9.8.8, Previously Disallowed Expense.

) The IRS is committed to the following: a. Issue internal procedures to monitor the cause of untimely payments, of implement necessary corrective actions, and promptly address inquiries. b. Ensure effective internal control systems are established and maintained as required. Administrative activities required for payments to witnesses are subject to periodic quality control validation to be conducted once annually. c. Ensure ﬁnancial management systems capabilities provide accurate and useful management reports on payments. d. Ensure the Inspector General and Internal Auditors review payment per- formance and systems accuracy, consistent with the Chief Financial Officers (CFO) Act requirements, and e. Ensure timely payments. (

) Witness fees and travel expenses are payable upon request to witnesses who are required to appear to give testimony or produce records before IRS Fees personnel in compliance with administrative summonses issued under IRC
, IRC
), IRC
), or IRC
). Amounts for these fees are prescribed in
USC

and are separate from reimbursement of third parties for search, transportation, and reproduction costs for summoned information. This includes a per diem rate and a rate per mile for associated travel. Witness fees and payments for mileage may be made to all summoned witnesses, whether a third-party witness, the taxpayer, or the taxpayer’s employee. Payment may be made whenever a summons is issued, regardless of the investigative state of the matter involved. (
) Procedures for payment of witness fees and travel expenses are detailed below. Use Standard Form (SF)
, Claims for Witness Attendance Fees, Travel and Miscellaneous Expenses (Original), for this purpose. a. The witness should prepare SF
with the assistance of an IRS em- ployee, if necessary, and sign in block

The name of the taxpayer should be shown under the name and case number in lines d and e, I, unless there is an assigned, non-SSN case number. Do not use the taxpayer’s Social Security Number (SSN) in line e. The IRS employee before whom the summoned party appears should review the claim and sign on line

, Part I and complete all information in Part III to indicate approval for payment. b. The fees paid to a witness are taxable income and, if the applicable dol- lar threshold is met during the year, a Form
will be issued. The So- cial Security Number of the witness must be included on SF
next their name on Line
of Part
-- Attendance Certiﬁcation. c. Forward SF

through channels to the appropriate Business Unit get Analyst for review and completion of the information in Parts I and The Budget Analyst will forward the request to CFO for payment. d. When the person summoned demands assurance or guarantee that ment will be made, prepare an additional copy of SF

and give the copy to the person. Insert the following statement: “Payment of witness fees and travel expenses as stated above are guaranteed by the Revenue Service” immediately above the space for approval. (
) If the person summoned cannot comply unless travel expenses are provided, then make an advance payment, not to exceed the amount allowable. Use the following procedures: (

) Payment for search, reproduction, and transportation costs will be made only to third parties served with a summons to produce third-party records or mation and only for material requested by the summons, unless the records are available to the general public. (

) Make payment only for search, reproduction, and transportation costs that both directly incurred and reasonably necessary. To determine whether costs are reasonably necessary, it is essential to consider search, reproduction, transportation costs separately. (
) Do not make any payment until the third party satisfactorily complies with summons. Note: Enforcement of the summons due to a third party’s partial summons ance can be made. (

) Do not make any payment unless the third party submits an itemized bill or invoice showing speciﬁc details concerning the search, reproduction, and transportation costs. Information that a third party must include on the is discussed in section IRM
, Review of Form
(Section A). (

grants authority to obligate appropriated funds for payment of search, reproduction, and transportation costs in connection with third-party summonses issued under the Internal enue laws. (08-09-2019) Obligational Payment Authority

Ensure Part B of the summons accompanies service of any summons and provide the witness with Form 6863, Invoice and Authorization for Payment of Administrative Summons Expenses. Upon full or satisfactory compliance with a summons, inform the witness that Form 6863 may be used to request reim-
Fees and Costs for Summoned Witnesses
) A third-party invoice resulting from compliance with a summons which is $
less ($

or less for revenue officers) may be paid in cash by the issuing employee with obligational authority. This threshold does not include amounts which are claimed separately as witness fees and mileage. Input a claim for reimbursement under Miscellaneous Expenses on the travel voucher and provide a copy of the third-party invoice with the signed voucher. This type may be claimed in conjunction with local or city-to-city travel expenses, and may not be claimed as the only expense on the travel voucher. Prior to paying the witness and signing the travel voucher:

Ensure the invoice itemizes the speciﬁc details of search, reproduction and transportation costs and that charges are at authorized rates. Forward a copy of the invoice to the official who initially approved the obligation or the official with obligation authority appropriate to the amount of the bill if other than the IRS employee. The obligating official will evaluate the charges in terms of accuracy and reasonableness and certify the bill for payment processing by signing following statement: “Payment is approved and is within my delegated obligational authority,” and print their title and organizational

) A witness may submit summoned information via electronic storage media, such as CD, DVD and thumb drives. Electronic format is normally less expensive and takes less time than paper documents, ultimately reducing summons invoice expenses. (
) Follow the procedures outlined in IRM
, Records on Encrypted Storage Media, when the witness provides the summoned information via elec- tronic storage media in lieu of paper documents. (

) If the witness claims expenses for submission of both paper documents and electronic media, verify that the paper records are different from the records provided on the CD. Notate on the invoice NO duplicate records on CD. Only allow the most cost effective expense claimed on the summons invoice when duplicate records are provided. A witness cannot be paid for duplicate repro- duction of information. Reﬂect the appropriate disallowed expenses on Line
a of Form
, Section B, and notify the third party of the adjustment.

If the witness claims expenses for submission of both paper documents and electronic media, verify that the paper records are different from the records provided on the CD. Notate on the invoice NO duplicate records on CD. Only allow the most cost effective expense claimed on the summons invoice when duplicate records are provided. A witness cannot be paid for duplicate repro- duction of information. Reﬂect the appropriate disallowed expenses on Line
a of Form
, Section B, and notify the third party of the adjustment.
Note: If the IRS employee requests both electronic and paper copies, the IRS must pay for both the electronic and paper copies.
) The witness is allowed search costs under Treas. Reg.
/ hour). (
) Send an e-mail to *CFO BFC Summons Help Desk when the witness includes a charge for providing the electronic records on storage media and the charges appear questionable. (
) A witness may respond to a summons by providing the summoned information via electronic transmission through a secure service or portal. See IRM
) The witness cannot claim expenses for paper documents when all information is provided via electronic transmission. Reﬂect the appropriate allowed expenses on Line
a of Form
, Section B, and notify the third party of the adjustment. (

) Upon receipt of an invoice at an IRS office, an employee should date stamp the Form

and forward the form to the IRS employee for review. If the Upon witness sends an unmarked or unidentiﬁable content package containing the summoned information prior to the “quash” date and it is opened and the invoice is date stamped at that time, the IRS employee should strike over the date stamp and reseal the material received. Re-open the package and re-stamp the invoice the day after the quash period expired. Notate on Form
the reason for the strike over of the ﬁrst date stamp. (

) After a third-party witness has satisfactorily complied with a summons, the employee must review any invoice within seven calendar days of receipt from a witness and either: • Return it to the witness for correction, or • Forward the invoice to CFO for payment processing. (

) The IRS employee is responsible for reviewing Section A for completeness submitted by the witness. If Section A is found to be complete and accurate, the IRS employee is responsible for completion and certiﬁcation of Section B of Form

and timely submission to CFO for payment. Incomplete sent to CFO may delay payment and impair the government’s ability to pay witness timely. Examples of invoice errors which delay invoice processing a. Untimely submissions b. Missing tax identiﬁcation number c. Missing accounting code data d. Missing signature and signature dates Note: CFO will return the Form
to the originating employee if are missing signatures and signature dates from the payee, the agent/officer, or the approving official. (
) Several line items of Section A must be completed by the witness for the

Upon receipt of an invoice at an IRS office, an employee should date stamp the Form 6863 and forward the form to the IRS employee for review. If the witness sends an unmarked or unidentiﬁable content package containing the summoned information prior to the “quash” date and it is opened prematurely and the invoice is date stamped at that time, the IRS employee should strike over the date stamp and reseal the material received. Re-open the package and re-stamp the invoice the day after the quash period expired. Notate on Form 6863 the reason for the strike over of the ﬁrst date stamp.
a. Line
- Payee’s Federal Tax Identiﬁcation Number (TIN): The witness must list their Federal Tax Identiﬁcation Number (TIN). b. Line
- Name and Address of Payee: The witness must include their full remittance name and address, to include the zip code. c. Line
- Name and Address of taxpayer to whose liability the summons relates: Self-explanatory.

Line
- Printed Name of Financial Institution Official or Payee: explanatory g. Line
- Title and Business E-mail Address: The Title of the employee of the witness is the only required item. An e-mail address not required for processing. h. Line
- Signature of Financial Institution Official or Payee: A signature is required for payment processing. i. Line
- Date Signed: The witness must date Form
j. Line
- Telephone Number: A contact number is required. (
) After a witness has satisfactorily complied with a summons, if any of the mation in the lines listed in paragraph (
) is missing or incomplete on the

received from the witness, the IRS employee must return the invoice the witness within seven calendar days with a document identifying the the witness must complete in order for the invoice to be processed. The employee can complete the missing information if known or if obtained the witness telephonically. However, if the IRS employee does not know cannot complete the missing information themselves and the invoice is not returned to witness and documented within seven days of the date stamp, IRS employee must obtain the missing information and process the invoice payment immediately. Note: The IRS employee can secure the missing line items verbally from the witness, but verbal communication does not extend the seven day time frame to return the invoice to the witness. The IRS employee must still the incomplete invoice to the witness within seven calendar days. (
) Section A of Form
does not require information on Lines
, and
b from the witness in order to be processed for payment. The invoice cannot returned to the witness for corrections or invoice processing delayed if the following lines are not completed: a. Line
- Payee’s Invoice Number: The witness can assign their own unique invoice number. This is helpful to monitor and track for control purposes. b. Line
- Payment Method: The witness completes this section in to receive payment via Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT). c. Line
b - Title and E-mail address: The title is required. An e-mail address is not. Note: Revenue officers using ICS, see IRM
, ICS Form

Provided the witness has satisfactorily complied with the summons, the IRS employee must review the invoice within seven calendar days to ensure all items required in Section A are contained on the invoice. If so, use the steps in the following table to process the invoice for payment:

Step Action 1 Complete and certify Section B of Form 6863. 2 Attach the witness’ invoice to Form 6863. 3 Write “See attached invoice” in the “Signature of ﬁnancial institution official or payee” line of Section A. 4 Transmit the documents to CFO as described in IRM 25.5.9.8.5, Invoice Submission to Chief Financial Officer Organization (CFO).

1 Complete and certify Section B of Form 6863. 2 Attach the witness’ invoice to Form 6863. 3 Write “See attached invoice” in the “Signature of ﬁnancial institution official or payee” line of Section A. 4 Transmit the documents to CFO as described in IRM 25.5.9.8.5, Invoice Submission to Chief Financial Officer Organization (CFO). ) Special procedures apply to courtesy summonses served in another area. a. When one area requests a summons to be served by another area, obligating authority official in the initiating area will obligate funds for payment of that summons. The requesting area will forward a summons, exclusive of the time and place for appearance and the before whom the witness is to appear. The transmittal document or Courtesy Investigation accompanying the summons should indicate level of obligation authority and Form

with the appropriate Office and funding codes. b. If the serving office anticipates costs to exceed the obligational the official indicated, the serving employee in the receiving area will advise the requesting area of the need for the approval of an official higher obligational authority.
(04-27-2017) Previously Disallowed Expense

When one area requests a summons to be served by another area, the obligating authority official in the initiating area will obligate funds for the payment of that summons. The requesting area will forward a summons, exclusive of the time and place for appearance and the before whom the witness is to appear. The transmittal document or Courtesy Investigation accompanying the summons should indicate the level of obligation authority and Form

with the appropriate Office and funding codes. If the serving office anticipates costs to exceed the obligational amount the official indicated, the serving employee in the receiving area will advise the requesting area of the need for the approval of an official higher obligational authority.

c. The IRS employee of the area serving the summons and the issuing official of the requesting area should coordinate to determine that ance has occurred. d. Within four calendar days of receipt from the witness who has rily complied with a summons, the serving employee will review the invoice for completeness as described in IRM
, Review of

(Section A). If invoice corrections are needed, the serving will fax or e-mail the invoice to the originating official in the requesting Area within four calendar days of invoice receipt or return the invoice to the witness for corrections within seven calendar days of receipt. e. Provided the witness has satisfactorily complied with the summons, the issuing official will review, certify for payment, and forward to CFO for payment processing within seven calendar days of original invoice receipt. ) If a petition to quash the summons is received timely and the summoned Information records have not been examined for completeness, the Form

invoice cannot be paid. A timely petition to quash prevents the IRS employee from viewing the records to determine if the summons is satisfactorily complied. When a petition to quash is received timely, the IRS employee will: • Keep a copy of the invoice with the administrative ﬁle. • Send the original invoice back to the witness with a cover letter ing that a petition to quash the summons was received and that we cannot pay the invoice until we can view the records to determine if summons was satisfactorily complied.

) If a petition to quash the summons is received timely and the summoned records have not been examined for completeness, the Form

invoice cannot be paid. A timely petition to quash prevents the IRS employee from viewing the records to determine if the summons is satisfactorily complied. When a petition to quash is received timely, the IRS employee will:

If a petition to quash the summons is received timely and the summoned records have not been examined for completeness, the Form 6863 invoice cannot be paid. A timely petition to quash prevents the IRS employee from viewing the records to determine if the summons is satisfactorily complied. When a petition to quash is received timely, the IRS employee will:
Keep a copy of the invoice with the administrative ﬁle. Send the original invoice back to the witness with a cover letter explain
ing that a petition to quash the summons was received and that we cannot pay the invoice until we can view the records to determine if the summons was satisfactorily complied.
